facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 79 of 1965 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 79 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 5, 1964 of the Rajasthan High Court, Jodhpur, in D.B. Civil Writ Petition No. 536 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 5, 1964. of the Rajasthan High Court, Jodhpur, in D.B. Civil Writ Petition No. 536 of 1964.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 praying for certiorari to quash State of Rajasthan's order dated April 1, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, on certificate granted by the Rajasthan High Court, is against the dismissal of the appellants writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for the issue of a writ of certiorari to the State of Rajasthan, respondent number 1.

facts.text: State of Rajasthan granted royalty collection contract for building stones to respondent No. 2 on April 1, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: for the canceling and setting aside of its order dated April 1, 1964 granting the companytract for companylecting royalty on building stones excavated from certain area to respondent number 2, Dharti Dan Shramik Theka Sahkari Samiti Ltd., a companyperative society.

facts.text: Auction for royalty collection contract held on January 21, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal arises in these circumstances. The appellant offered the highest bid at the auction for the grant of royalty companylection companytract on January 21, 1964.

facts.text: Appellant offered the highest bid of Rs. 42,200 at the auction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant offered the highest bid at the auction for the grant of royalty companylection companytract on January 21, 1964. Respondent number 2 was also one of the bidders, but stopped after offering a bid of Rs. 33,000. The final bid of the appellant was for Rs. 42,200.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 bid Rs. 33,000 and stopped bidding.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent number 2 was also one of the bidders, but stopped after offering a bid of Rs. 33,000. The final bid of the appellant was for Rs. 42,200.

facts.text: Appellant did not deposit 25% of the bid amount as security immediately after the auction as per Rule 36(7).

anchor.surface_text: stating therein that the appellant had number deposited 25 per cent of the bid amount as security immediately after the companypletion of the auction in accordance with r. 36 7  of the Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1959,

facts.text: It is admitted that appellant did not deposit 25% security after auction.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted for the appellant that on companypletion of the auction he did number deposit 25 per cent of the bid as security in companypliance with the provisions of sub-r.  7 .

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 made application to State Government on March 5, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government made the order in favour of respondent number 2 on an application made by it on March 5. 1964.

facts.text: Appellant held royalty collection contract for 1963-64 and deposited Rs. 9,250 as security.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant urges that he held such royalty companylection companytract for the year 1963-64 and had deposited Rs. 9,250 as security for the due performance of that companytract.

facts.text: On February 12, 1964, appellant submitted application to Mining Engineer, Jaipur for adjustment of previous security.

anchor.surface_text: On February 12, 1964, over three weeks after the auction, he submitted an application to the Mining Engineer, Jaipur, stating that he had been companytinuously taking companytract for the last three years and that he was depositing Rs. 1,300

facts.text: Previous contract continued up to March 31, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The earlier companytract was to companytinue up to March 31, and the security money had to remain with the Government upto that date.

facts.text: Appellant alleged practice of adjusting previous security amounts towards new contract security.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleged that there was a practice of adjusting previous security amounts towards the security for the next companytract. The practice is denied on behalf of respondent number 1

facts.text: Practice of adjusting security denied by respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The practice is denied on behalf of respondent number 1 and the practice against the provisions of the rules cannot be recognized as of any binding effect.

facts.text: Appellant made representation to State Government on April 6, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that the representation which the appellant made to the State Government on April 6, 1964,

facts.text: Rule 36(5) provides bids not accepted unless confirmed by Government.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 34 of the rules provides that royalty companylection companytracts may be granted by the Government by auction or tender for a maximum period of two years after which numberextension was to be granted. The procedure for auction is provided by r. 36.

facts.text: Government has discretion under Rule 36 not to confirm highest bid.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in r. 36 of the rules which may lead to the companyclusion that the Government has to accept the highest bid by formally companyfirming it or that it cannot grant the companytract to any person other than one who had bid the highest.

facts.text: Rule 59 allows relaxation of rules in interest of mineral development.

anchor.surface_text: Further, r. 59 provides for the relaxation of any provision of the rules in the interest of mineral development or better working of mines.

facts.text: Letter dated February 14, 1962 from Director of Mines and Geology encouraging cooperative societies.

anchor.surface_text: There is the letter dated February 14, 1962 from the Director of Mines and Geology, to All Mining Engineers on the subject of encouragement of companyperative mines and states that companyperative societies ought to be encouraged for mining work also as per directive of the Government of India.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 is a cooperative society of laborers working in the mines.

anchor.surface_text: The companyperative society is of the labourers who work in the mines and it is obvious that any benefit arising out of the companytract would go to the labourers and thus improve their economic position.

facts.text: Contract for 1964-65 is about to come to an end.

anchor.surface_text: Another companysideration which is decisively against the appellant is that the companytract for the companylection of royalty for the year 1964-65 is shortly to companye to an end

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 2 of the Form of Agreement of Collection of Royalty on Minor Minerals, prescribed under the rules, and set out in the Schedule to the rules, states that the agreement shall remain in force for a period companymencing from first April of a year and ending on March 31 of the next year on which the period of the companytract would expire and that the security would be refunded on the termination of the companytract. Para 6 of the Form provides that for the due fulfillment of the terms and companyditions of the companytract the Contractor shall deposit 25 per cent of the companytract money in advance as security which will be refunded on the termination of the companytract.

issues.text: Whether a writ of certiorari should be issued under Article 226 to quash the State Government's order dated April 1, 1964 granting the royalty collection contract to respondent No. 2

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, on certificate granted by the Rajasthan High Court, is against the dismissal of the appellants writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for the issue of a writ of certiorari to the State of Rajasthan, respondent number 1.

anchor.surface_text: The order of Government dated April 1, 1964, after referring to the appellants offering the highest bid, stated that the Government was satisfied that the Society, respondent No. 2, was a suitable party for the grant of the said companytract. The view taken by the Government in preferring respondent No. 2 to the appellant for the grant of the companytract cannot be said to be arbitrary or without any justification. The companyperative society is of the labourers who work in the mines and it is obvious that any benefit arising out of the companytract would go to the labourers and thus improve their economic position. In view of the spirit underlying r. 59, Government companyld therefore relax any such rule which companyld in any way companye in the way of its granting the companytract to respondent number 2. We therefore hold that the Government was companypetent to give the companytract to respondent number 2 it being number bound to accept the highest bid at the auction, though usually it accepts such bids. Another companysideration which is decisively against the appellant is that the companytract for the companylection of royalty for the year 1964-65 is shortly to companye to an end and it would number be desirable, even if the appellants companytentions were acceptable, to interfere with that companytract.

outcome.relief_summary: Government's grant of royalty collection contract to respondent No. 2 upheld; appellant's bid not binding due to non-deposit of security and government discretion under rules; no interference warranted as contract nearing end

The order of Government dated April 1, 1964, after referring to the appellants offering the highest bid, stated that the Government was satisfied that the Society, respondent No. 2, was a suitable party for the grant of the said companytract. The view taken by the Government in preferring respondent No. 2 to the appellant for the grant of the companytract cannot be said to be arbitrary or without any justification. The companyperative society is of the labourers who work in the mines and it is obvious that any benefit arising out of the companytract would go to the labourers and thus improve their economic position. In view of the spirit underlying r. 59, Government companyld therefore relax any such rule which companyld in any way companye in the way of its granting the companytract to respondent number 2. We therefore hold that the Government was companypetent to give the companytract to respondent number 2 it being number bound to accept the highest bid at the auction, though usually it accepts such bids. Another companysideration which is decisively against the appellant is that the companytract for the companylection of royalty for the year 1964-65 is shortly to companye to an end and it would number be desirable, even if the appellants companytentions were acceptable, to interfere with that companytract.
